newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Treasuries a touch higher at open, eye NAPM.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Treasuries a touch higher at open, eye NAPM.

text.p: U.S. Treasuries opened marginally higher in coupons and a touch lower in bills as players geared up for the monthly report from the National Association of Purchasing Management (NAPM).
At 0800 EST/1300 GMT, the benchmark 30-year bond was up 1/32 at 94-5/32 to yield 7.1 percent. The two-year note was up 1/32 at 99-22/32, yielding 6.42 percent.

The NAPM index of manufacturing activity, set for release at 1000 EST/1500 GMT, was expected to set the tone for the rest of the week. Economists forecast the index would rise to 53.6 in March from 53.1 in February.
"Today NAPM ... is going to be the key situation," said Larry Dyer, government strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston.
NAPM components such as delivery times and prices help measure demand and provide clues to future monetary policy, he said.
"You look at what (Federal Reserve Chairman Alan) Greenspan has told us, and it's that real demand is running too high," Dyer said. "Leading indicators coming out of NAPM are going to be key."
Both the deliveries and prices measures rose between January and February, and many analysts forecast at least slight rises again in March.
Besides NAPM, the market will pore over weekly retail sales reports from BTM/Schroders and Redbook Research, as well as the monthly leading indicators and construction spending releases.
Economists forecast leaders rose 0.4 percent in February against 0.3 percent in January, and they projected construction spending climbed 0.9 percent last month against 0.4 percent the month before.
In overseas trading, bills again caught a lift as money continued to flow from equities into front-end Treasuries.
A few analysts have said bills seem overpriced, but others said the selloff following last Tuesday's Fed interest rate hike was overdone and further improvement is likely.
"We've done well since the Fed tightened because people got a little too scared in the front end," Credit Suisse's Dyer said.
Bills now appear priced for another rate hike in July rather than at the May 20 Federal Open Market Committee meeting, he said.
At 0830 EST/1330 GMT, three-month bill rates were up one basis point at 5.19 percent. Six- and 12-month rates were unchanged at 5.32 percent and 5.67 percent, respectively.
Five-year note prices were unchanged at 99-14/32 to yield 6.76 percent, and 10-year notes were unchanged at 95-11/32 to yield 6.91 percent.
